courses.name: Introduction to Computing
courses.description: The aim of this course is to introduce fundamental computing concepts to first year college students. The course focuses on working in teams, group functioning, designing programming, use functional programming, and how to effectively use computers.
courses.keywords: computing basics, binary, algorithms, hardware and software, data representation, internet, security, spreadsheets, databases, AI, ethics

content.topic: What is Computing? History of computers, hardware vs. software, binary representation
How Computers Work — CPU, memory, storage, I/O devices, operating systems basics
Digital Information — Data representation, bits and bytes, text encoding, digital images
Introduction to Algorithms — Problem-solving, flowcharts, pseudocode, step-by-step thinking
Introduction to Programming Concepts — Variables, basic data types, simple expressions
Control Structures — Conditionals (if/else), simple loops, logical thinking
Functions and Modularity — Breaking problems into smaller parts, code reuse basics
Data Organization — Lists, simple data structures, working with collections
Networks and the Internet — How the internet works, protocols, web basics, URLs, browsers
Computer Security and Privacy — Passwords, encryption basics, online safety, privacy concerns
Spreadsheets and Data Analysis — Using spreadsheets for computation, formulas, basic charts
Databases and Information Management — How data is stored and retrieved, basic queries
Artificial Intelligence and Current Topics — Machine learning basics, AI applications, ethics
Computing in Society — Social impact of computing, career paths, course review

courses.name: Introduction to Object-Oriented Programming
courses.description: This course introduces the fundamentals of Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) using Java, covering core concepts such as classes, methods, encapsulation, inheritance, and polymorphism. Students will develop problem-solving skills through hands-on exercises.
courses.keywords: Java, object-oriented programming, classes, inheritance, polymorphism, arrays, exceptions, file I/O

content.topic: Introduction to Java — JVM, IDE setup, first program, compilation, basic syntax
Variables and Data Types — Primitive types, declarations, type casting, operators
Expressions and Basic I/O — Arithmetic expressions, Scanner for input, print statements
Control Flow I — Conditional statements (if, if-else, switch), boolean expressions
Control Flow II — Loops (for, while, do-while), nested control structures
Methods — Defining methods, parameters, return values, method overloading
Introduction to Classes and Objects — Class design, instance variables, constructors, this keyword
Object-Oriented Design — Encapsulation, access modifiers, getters/setters, object interaction
Arrays — Array declaration, initialization, traversal, arrays of objects, ArrayList introduction
Inheritance — Superclasses/subclasses, extends keyword, method overriding, super keyword
Polymorphism and Abstract Classes — Dynamic binding, abstract methods, designing class hierarchies
Interfaces and Packages — Interface definition, implementing interfaces, organizing code in packages
Exception Handling — Try-catch blocks, throwing exceptions, checked vs. unchecked exceptions
File I/O and Course Review — Reading/writing files, streams, comprehensive review

courses.name: Introduction to Programming with Python
courses.description: This course aims to equip engineering students who are not specializing in computing with the necessary skills to design and implement simple computer programs of practical use in Python to solve mathematical and scientific problems.
courses.keywords: Python, introductory programming, control flow, functions, lists, dictionaries, OOP basics

content.topic: Introduction to Computing and Python — What is programming, Python setup, first program, print statements
Variables and Data Types — Integers, floats, strings, booleans, type conversion, basic operators
Expressions and User Input — Arithmetic expressions, input function, string operations
Control Flow I — Conditional statements (if, elif, else), boolean logic, comparison operators
Control Flow II — While loops, for loops, range function, loop patterns, break/continue
Functions — Defining functions, parameters, return values, scope, docstrings
Strings and String Processing — String methods, slicing, formatting, text manipulation
Lists — List creation, indexing, slicing, list methods, iteration over lists
Tuples and Dictionaries — Immutable sequences, key-value pairs, dictionary operations
File I/O — Opening files, reading/writing, file handling patterns, CSV files
Testing and Debugging — Testing strategies, debugging techniques, assertions, common errors
Object-Oriented Programming Basics — Classes, objects, init, instance methods, self
More OOP and Modules — Inheritance basics, importing modules, using standard libraries
Algorithm Efficiency and Review — Big-O introduction, searching, sorting basics, course review

courses.name: Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science
courses.description: Bu ders, temel matematik tanımlarını ve bilgisayar bilimleri ve mühendislik uygulamalarını kapsamaktadır. Bu dersin sonunda öğrenciler, teorik matematik ile pratik bilgisayar bilimleri ve mühendisliği arasındaki ilişki ile donanmış olurlar.
courses.keywords: discrete mathematics, logic, sets, functions, relations, induction, counting, probability, graph theory

content.topic: Propositional Logic I — Propositions, logical connectives (AND, OR, NOT), truth tables
Propositional Logic II — Logical equivalence, implications, contrapositive, normal forms
Predicate Logic — Predicates, quantifiers (universal, existential), nested quantifiers
Proof Techniques I — Direct proof, proof by contraposition, proof by contradiction
Proof Techniques II — Proof by cases, existence proofs, constructive vs. non-constructive
Sets and Set Operations — Set notation, subsets, union, intersection, complement, power sets
Functions — One-to-one, onto, bijections, inverse functions, composition
Relations — Properties of relations, equivalence relations, partial orderings
Mathematical Induction — Weak induction, strong induction, well-ordering principle
Recursion and Recurrence Relations — Recursive definitions, solving recurrences
Counting I — Basic counting principles, sum rule, product rule, pigeonhole principle
Counting II — Permutations, combinations, binomial coefficients, Pascal's triangle
Introduction to Probability — Sample spaces, events, conditional probability, Bayes' theorem
Graph Theory Basics — Graph terminology, types of graphs, paths, connectivity, trees

courses.name: Data Structures and Algorithms
courses.description: This course covers the basic science behind the use of computers to provide effective and efficient methods for carrying out tasks. This course introduces the basic sorting and searching methods and dynamic data structures such as linked lists, trees and hash tables.
courses.keywords: data structures, algorithms, complexity, arrays, linked lists, trees, graphs, sorting, hashing

content.topic: Introduction to Algorithms and Complexity Analysis — Big-O, Big-Omega, Big-Theta notation
Arrays, Dynamic Arrays, and Amortized Analysis
Linked Lists (Singly, Doubly, Circular) and Abstract Data Types
Stacks, Queues, and Deques
Recursion and Basic Sorting — Bubble sort, selection sort, insertion sort
Divide-and-Conquer — Merge sort and quicksort
Binary Trees — Tree traversals and binary search trees
Balanced Trees — AVL trees, red-black trees
Heaps and Priority Queues
Hash Tables — Hash functions and collision resolution
Introduction to Graphs — Representations, BFS, and DFS
Graph Applications — Topological sort and connected components
Shortest Path Algorithms — Dijkstra's, Bellman-Ford
Minimum Spanning Trees — Prim's, Kruskal's algorithms, course review

courses.name: Modern DevOps Practices
courses.description: In this course on Modern DevOps Practices, students dive deep into the transformative methodologies that are revolutionizing how development and operations teams collaborate. This course provides a practical understanding of how to implement and leverage modern DevOps practices.
courses.keywords: DevOps, CI/CD, Docker, Kubernetes, Terraform, Ansible, monitoring, cloud, automation

content.topic: Introduction to DevOps — Philosophy, culture, principles, Dev/Ops collaboration
Linux Fundamentals — Command-line navigation, shell scripting, system monitoring
Version Control with Git — Branching strategies, merging, pull requests, Git workflows
Continuous Integration — CI principles, build automation, Jenkins/GitHub Actions
Continuous Delivery and Deployment — CD pipelines, deployment strategies (blue-green, canary)
Containerization with Docker — Container basics, Dockerfiles, images, volumes, multi-stage builds
Docker Compose — Multi-container applications, YAML configuration, Docker networking
Kubernetes Fundamentals — Architecture, pods, services, deployments, kubectl
Advanced Kubernetes — ConfigMaps, secrets, persistent volumes, Helm charts
Infrastructure as Code with Terraform — IaC principles, configuration, state management
Configuration Management with Ansible — Playbooks, inventory, roles, idempotency
Cloud Platforms for DevOps — AWS/Azure/GCP DevOps services
Monitoring and Observability — Prometheus, Grafana, ELK stack, SRE principles
DevOps Security and Best Practices — DevSecOps, container security, secrets management

courses.name: Theory of Computation
courses.description: This course teaches regular languages, context-free languages and the automata related to these: finite-state automata and push-down automata. The machinery are explained and studied mathematically. Also, regular grammars and context-free grammars and regular expressions are studied extensively.
courses.keywords: theory of computation, automata, regular languages, context-free languages, Turing machines, decidability, complexity, NP-completeness

content.topic: Introduction to Theory of Computation — Mathematical preliminaries and proof techniques
Finite Automata — Deterministic Finite Automata (DFA)
Nondeterministic Finite Automata (NFA) — NFA-DFA equivalence
Regular Expressions — Regular languages and closure properties
Pumping Lemma for Regular Languages — Non-regular languages
Context-Free Grammars (CFG) — Parse trees, ambiguity
Pushdown Automata (PDA) — CFG-PDA equivalence
Pumping Lemma for Context-Free Languages — Closure properties of CFLs
Turing Machines — Definition, variants, and Church-Turing thesis
Decidability — Decidable languages, the Halting Problem
Reducibility — Rice's theorem, undecidable problems
Time Complexity — P and NP, polynomial-time reducibility
NP-Completeness — Cook-Levin theorem, NP-complete problems
Space Complexity (PSPACE) — Course review

courses.name: Advanced Data Structures and Algorithms
courses.description: This course builds on CMPE 211 to apply similar techniques to analyse more sophisticated algorithms and data structures. Topics covered include graphs and graph algorithms, greedy algorithms, random algorithms, divide and conquer algorithms, dynamic programming and string searching algorithms.
courses.keywords: advanced algorithms, dynamic programming, network flow, NP-hard, approximation algorithms, randomized algorithms

content.topic: Review of Asymptotic Analysis — Recurrences and the Master Theorem
Amortized Analysis — Aggregate, accounting, potential methods
Dynamic Programming I — Principles, memoization vs. tabulation
Dynamic Programming II — Classic problems (LCS, edit distance, knapsack)
Advanced Graph Algorithms — Strongly connected components, all-pairs shortest paths
Network Flow I — Ford-Fulkerson, max-flow min-cut theorem
Network Flow II — Applications (bipartite matching, minimum cut)
Linear Programming — Formulation, duality, and simplex overview
NP-Completeness — Formal definitions, reductions, proving NP-completeness
Coping with NP-Hardness — Backtracking, branch-and-bound
Approximation Algorithms I — Vertex cover, set cover, TSP
Approximation Algorithms II — Approximation schemes (PTAS, FPTAS)
Randomized Algorithms — Las Vegas vs. Monte Carlo, randomized quicksort, min-cut
Advanced Topics — String matching or computational geometry, course review

courses.name: Data Science and Social Media Analysis
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with a general understanding of data science and social media analysis, including their design. In addition, the design processes for and programming used in developing such systems will be addressed.
courses.keywords: data science, social media, APIs, network analysis, sentiment analysis, topic modeling, ethics

content.topic: Introduction to Social Media Data Science — Data types, structured vs. unstructured data
Social Media APIs and Data Collection — Working with Twitter, Reddit, YouTube APIs
Data Storage and Management — NoSQL databases, JSON handling, data preprocessing
Exploratory Data Analysis — Summary statistics, temporal patterns, geographic analysis
Network Fundamentals — Graph theory basics, social network representations
Network Analysis Metrics — Centrality measures (degree, betweenness, closeness)
Community Detection and Clustering — Graph clustering algorithms, modularity
Midterm Exam and Review
Text Processing Fundamentals — Tokenization, stemming, lemmatization, TF-IDF
Sentiment Analysis — Lexicon-based approaches, machine learning classifiers
Topic Modeling — LDA, topic extraction over time, hashtag analysis
Influence and Virality — Information diffusion, influencer identification
Ethical Considerations — Privacy, consent, data governance, research ethics
Final Project Presentations and Course Wrap-up

courses.name: Concurrent Programming
courses.description: This course offers an exploration of the widely used programming languages C++, Python, and Java, focusing on their unique strengths and areas of application. Students will delve into topics such as object-oriented programming, concurrency, concurrent process design, critical section access, mutual exclusion, threads, semaphores, and sockets.
courses.keywords: concurrency, threads, synchronization, locks, semaphores, deadlock, parallel programming, memory models

content.topic: Introduction to Concurrency — Motivation, processes vs. threads, safety and liveness properties
Thread Fundamentals — Thread creation, Java threads, Python threading, POSIX threads
Shared Memory and Race Conditions — Shared data problems, atomicity, critical sections
Mutual Exclusion — Peterson's algorithm, test-and-set, compare-and-swap
Locks and Lock-based Synchronization — Mutex locks, reentrant locks, reader-writer locks
Semaphores — Counting and binary semaphores, producer-consumer problem
Monitors and Condition Variables — Monitor concept, Java synchronized, wait/notify
Midterm Exam and Review
Deadlock and Livelock — Deadlock conditions, prevention, detection, recovery
Concurrent Data Structures — Thread-safe collections, lock-free data structures
Parallel Programming Patterns — Fork-join, map-reduce, OpenMP basics, thread pools
Memory Models and Atomics — Java memory model, happens-before, volatile, memory barriers
Actor Model and Message Passing — Actor-based concurrency, async programming patterns
Advanced Topics and Project Presentations — Transactional memory, parallel algorithm design

courses.name: Cloud Programming
courses.description: Programs running on the cloud to provide services to users or computers elsewhere are becoming increasingly important. This course looks at the issues involved in writing service-providing programs, using the latest programming languages and technology.
courses.keywords: cloud programming, microservices, REST APIs, serverless, containers, message queues, observability, security

content.topic: Introduction to Cloud-Native Development — Cloud computing overview, 12-factor app methodology
Cloud Service Models — IaaS, PaaS, SaaS, FaaS comparison
Microservices Architecture — Monolith vs. microservices, decomposition strategies
RESTful API Design — REST principles, API design best practices, Flask/Express
API Documentation and Testing — OpenAPI/Swagger, API testing with Postman
Containerizing Cloud Applications — Docker for microservices, image optimization
Service Communication Patterns — Synchronous vs. asynchronous, API gateways
Serverless Computing Fundamentals — AWS Lambda, Azure Functions, Google Cloud Functions
Serverless Application Development — Event-driven functions, triggers, cold starts
Message Queues and Event-Driven Architecture — Kafka, RabbitMQ, SQS, pub/sub patterns
Container Orchestration for Microservices — Kubernetes, service mesh (Istio)
Cloud Database Services — Managed databases, NoSQL, database-per-service pattern
Observability in Cloud Applications — Distributed tracing, logging, OpenTelemetry
Cloud Application Security — OAuth/JWT authentication, secrets management, final project

courses.name: Data Engineering
courses.description: In this course, students will learn about many engineering tasks related to data. Students will specialize in many topics such as data visualization, data analysis, linear regression, and modeling. These topics will be reinforced with both theoretical and practical examples.
courses.keywords: data engineering, data pipelines, ETL, SQL, data lakes, data warehouses, Spark, Airflow, governance

content.topic: Introduction to Data Engineering — Role of data engineers, modern data stack overview
Data Pipeline Fundamentals — End-to-end architecture, batch vs. streaming
SQL Review and Advanced Queries — Aggregate functions, joins, window functions
Source Systems and Data Ingestion — Operational databases, APIs, file formats (CSV, JSON, Parquet)
Data Lakes and Data Warehouses — Architecture comparison, data lakehouses
Data Modeling for Analytics — ER diagrams, dimensional modeling, star schema
ETL/ELT Processes — Extract, Transform, Load patterns, dbt
Midterm Exam and Review
Big Data Fundamentals — Hadoop ecosystem, HDFS, MapReduce concepts
Apache Spark — Spark architecture, RDDs, DataFrames, PySpark basics
Data Quality and Profiling — Data validation, quality metrics, handling missing data
Data Orchestration and Scheduling — Workflow orchestration, Apache Airflow
Data Governance and Catalogs — Metadata management, data lineage, compliance
Final Project Presentations — End-to-end pipeline demonstration

courses.name: Machine Learning
courses.description: Machine learning concerns the construction of systems that can learn from data. This course covers the theory and practical algorithms for machine learning focusing on classification, clustering, dimensionality reduction and reinforcement learning.
courses.keywords: machine learning, classification, regression, SVM, neural networks, deep learning, clustering, ensembles, reinforcement learning

content.topic: Introduction to Machine Learning — Supervised vs. unsupervised learning, model evaluation
Decision Trees — ID3, information gain, entropy, pruning
k-Nearest Neighbors — Instance-based learning, distance metrics
Linear Models I — Perceptron algorithm, linear separability
Linear Models II — Linear regression, gradient descent, optimization
Logistic Regression — Maximum likelihood estimation, regularization (L1/L2)
Support Vector Machines — Linear SVMs, kernels, soft margins
Neural Networks I — Multilayer perceptrons, backpropagation algorithm
Neural Networks II — Deep learning basics, activation functions, training techniques
Convolutional Neural Networks — CNNs, applications in computer vision
Unsupervised Learning — K-means clustering, hierarchical clustering, GMMs, EM algorithm
Dimensionality Reduction — PCA, feature selection
Ensemble Methods — Bagging, random forests, boosting/AdaBoost
Reinforcement Learning Introduction — Learning theory (PAC, VC dimension), course review

courses.name: Computer Graphics
courses.description: This course offers a comprehensive introduction to the field of computer graphics, covering fundamental concepts, algorithms, and techniques for both two-dimensional and three-dimensional graphics. Advanced rendering techniques such as ray tracing is also introduced.
courses.keywords: computer graphics, 2D graphics, 3D graphics, transformations, OpenGL, shading, texturing, ray tracing

content.topic: Introduction to Computer Graphics — History, applications, graphics pipeline, coordinate systems
Linear Algebra Review and 2D Graphics — Vectors, matrices, rasterization (Bresenham's algorithm)
2D Transformations — Translation, rotation, scaling, homogeneous coordinates
3D Transformations — 3D coordinate systems, rotation matrices, Euler angles, quaternions
Viewing and Projection — Camera models, orthographic and perspective projection
Graphics Pipeline and OpenGL/WebGL — Modern pipeline, vertex and fragment processing
Programmable Shaders — GLSL fundamentals, vertex shaders, fragment shaders
Midterm Exam and Polygon Rendering — Scan conversion, clipping, hidden surface removal
Illumination and Reflection Models — Phong reflection model (ambient, diffuse, specular)
Shading Techniques — Flat, Gouraud, and Phong shading, per-pixel lighting
Texture Mapping — Texture coordinates, filtering (mipmapping), bump mapping
Advanced Rendering Techniques — Shadow mapping, deferred rendering, anti-aliasing
Ray Tracing Fundamentals — Ray-object intersection, recursive ray tracing, acceleration structures
Advanced Topics — Global illumination, GPU computing, final projects

courses.name: Machine Translation
courses.description: The aim of this course is to teach primary concepts and programming skills about machine translation (MT) and train students who have fundamental understandings about MT applications. Students gain experience about coding with python and learn using python libraries effectively.
courses.keywords: machine translation, SMT, NMT, transformers, BLEU, evaluation, low-resource MT

content.topic: Introduction to Machine Translation — History (rule-based, statistical, neural), evaluation challenges
Linguistic Foundations — Morphology, word alignment problems
Statistical Machine Translation I — Noisy channel model, IBM Models 1 and 2
Statistical Machine Translation II — Phrase-based translation, language models
MT Evaluation Metrics — BLEU, METEOR, TER, ROUGE, human evaluation
Neural Network Foundations for MT — Word embeddings, encoder-decoder framework
Sequence-to-Sequence Models — RNN/LSTM-based translation
Attention Mechanisms — Bahdanau attention, Luong attention, visualization
Transformer Architecture I — Self-attention, positional encoding, multi-head attention
Transformer Architecture II — Complete transformer model, layer normalization
Subword Tokenization — BPE, WordPiece, SentencePiece, handling rare words
Advanced NMT Topics — Multilingual MT, zero-shot translation, transfer learning
Low-Resource Machine Translation — Domain adaptation, back-translation
Current Trends — Large language models for MT, quality estimation, project presentations

courses.name: Operating Systems
courses.description: Operating systems play a fundamental role in the use of computers and are of enormous commercial importance. Contents include classification and structure of operating systems, storage media, memory management and dynamic storage strategies, scheduling algorithms, I/O and interrupt structures, protection and security.
courses.keywords: operating systems, processes, threads, scheduling, synchronization, deadlocks, virtual memory, file systems, security

content.topic: Introduction to Operating Systems — History, OS roles, system calls, kernel vs. user mode
Processes — Process concept, process states, PCB, context switching, process creation
Threads — Thread models, user vs. kernel threads, multithreading, Pthreads programming
CPU Scheduling — Scheduling criteria, algorithms (FCFS, SJF, priority, round-robin)
Process Synchronization I — Critical section problem, Peterson's solution, mutex locks
Process Synchronization II — Semaphores, classical problems (producer-consumer, dining philosophers)
Deadlocks — Deadlock characterization, prevention, avoidance (Banker's algorithm), detection
Memory Management — Address spaces, address binding, swapping, contiguous allocation, paging
Virtual Memory — Demand paging, page faults, page replacement algorithms, thrashing
Storage Management — Disk structure, disk scheduling (FCFS, SSTF, SCAN), RAID
File Systems I — File concepts, access methods, directory structure, file sharing
File Systems II — File system implementation, allocation methods, free-space management
I/O Systems — I/O hardware, application I/O interface, interrupt handling, DMA
Protection and Security — Access control, authentication, security threats, virtualization overview

courses.name: Computer Architecture
courses.description: This course is the continuation of Digital Design course where logic gates, combinational and sequential circuits are studied. Starting from register design, memory design, ALU, datapath design are covered. Instruction set architecture with examples are covered. RISC and CISC architectures are reviewed.
courses.keywords: computer architecture, ISA, pipelines, hazards, caching, virtual memory, ILP, multiprocessors, GPUs

content.topic: Introduction to Computer Architecture — Performance metrics, Amdahl's Law, ISA abstraction
Instruction Set Architecture — RISC vs. CISC, MIPS/RISC-V instruction formats, addressing modes
Digital Logic Review — Combinational logic, multiplexers, ALU design, sequential logic
Single-Cycle Processor Design — Datapath components, control unit design, instruction execution
Multi-Cycle Processor Design — Breaking instructions into stages, microprogrammed control
Pipelining Fundamentals — 5-stage pipeline (IF, ID, EX, MEM, WB), throughput vs. latency
Pipeline Hazards I — Structural hazards, data hazards, forwarding/bypassing, stalling
Pipeline Hazards II — Control hazards, branch prediction (static and dynamic)
Memory Hierarchy — Locality principles, cache basics, direct-mapped caches
Advanced Caching — Set-associative caches, replacement policies, write policies
Virtual Memory — Address translation, page tables, TLBs, page faults, memory protection
Instruction-Level Parallelism — Superscalar processors, out-of-order execution, Tomasulo's algorithm
Multiprocessors and Parallelism — SIMD, MIMD, cache coherence protocols (MESI)
Advanced Topics — GPUs, VLIW architectures, power/energy considerations, course review

courses.name: Network Programming
courses.description: This course looks at programming for network based systems. Subjects covered include network protocols, network traffic and security, distributed programming and emerging network technologies. The course includes practical network programming.
courses.keywords: network programming, sockets, TCP, UDP, concurrency, HTTP, RPC, distributed systems, security

content.topic: Introduction to Network Programming — OSI and TCP/IP models, client-server paradigm
Socket Programming Basics — Socket API, socket types, socket system calls
TCP Client Programming — Creating TCP clients, connecting to servers, sending/receiving data
TCP Server Programming — Iterative servers, connection handling, server design patterns
UDP Programming — Connectionless communication, UDP client/server, sendto/recvfrom
Network Byte Order and Addressing — Byte ordering, address structures, hostname resolution (DNS)
I/O Multiplexing — select(), poll(), non-blocking I/O, event-driven programming, epoll
Concurrent Servers I — Multi-process servers using fork(), process management
Concurrent Servers II — Multi-threaded servers using Pthreads, thread synchronization, thread pools
Application Protocols — HTTP protocol basics, building HTTP clients and servers
Remote Procedure Calls — RPC concepts, gRPC/Protocol Buffers
Distributed Systems Fundamentals — Distributed architectures, CAP theorem introduction
Network Security Basics — SSL/TLS overview, secure sockets, authentication
Advanced Topics — Raw sockets, multicast, network debugging (tcpdump, Wireshark), project presentations

courses.name: Software Engineering
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with an introductory understanding of general problems in developing large-scale computer systems that require teamwork, and also the basic principles in planning for tools to develop such systems in economically feasible ways.
courses.keywords: software engineering, SDLC, agile, requirements, UML, architecture, testing, CI, project management

content.topic: Introduction to Software Engineering and Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC)
Software Process Models — Waterfall, iterative, spiral, V-Model
Agile Methodologies — Scrum, Extreme Programming (XP)
Requirements Engineering — Elicitation techniques
Requirements Specification and Use Case Modeling
System Modeling with UML — Class, sequence, state diagrams
Software Architecture and Architectural Patterns
Design Principles — SOLID, coupling, cohesion, and design patterns
Version Control Systems (Git) and Configuration Management
Software Testing Fundamentals — Unit, integration, system testing
Test-Driven Development and Continuous Integration
Code Reviews, Static Analysis, and Quality Assurance
Project Management, Risk Management, and Estimation
Software Evolution, Maintenance, and DevOps Practices

courses.name: Business Intelligence and Analytics
courses.description: This course covers Business Intelligence as a concept of data collection and management to support wide variety of management tasks and Business Analytics as an extensive use of data analysis methods have gained great importance to drive fact-based decisions and actions.
courses.keywords: business intelligence, data warehousing, OLAP, dashboards, KPIs, visualization, predictive analytics, governance

content.topic: Introduction to Business Intelligence — BI concepts, decision support systems, BI lifecycle
Data Warehousing Fundamentals — OLTP vs. OLAP, data warehouse architecture, data marts
Dimensional Modeling — Facts, dimensions, measures, star schema, slowly changing dimensions
ETL for Data Warehouses — Extraction strategies, transformation, loading techniques
OLAP and Multidimensional Analysis — OLAP cubes, drill-down, roll-up, slice, dice
SQL for Analytics — Advanced SQL, window functions, OLAP extensions
Introduction to BI Tools — Overview of Tableau, Power BI, Looker
Midterm Exam and Review
Data Visualization Principles — Visual encoding, chart selection, dashboard design
Building Interactive Dashboards — Filters, parameters, calculated fields
Reporting and KPIs — Report design, key performance indicators, scorecards
Advanced Analytics — Predictive analytics introduction, trend analysis, forecasting
Data Quality and Governance in BI — Data quality dimensions, master data management
BI Strategy and Final Project Presentations — Analytics maturity models

courses.name: Natural Language Processing
courses.description: Natural Language Processing (NLP) which is sub-brunch of Artificial intelligence, aims to develop techniques for processing language and speech. The course aims to learn basic algorithms in this field and the main language levels: morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics.
courses.keywords: natural language processing, word embeddings, language models, parsing, RNNs, transformers, sentiment analysis, QA

content.topic: Introduction to NLP — Language and computation, regular expressions, text normalization
Word Representations I — Word vectors and Word2Vec (Skip-gram, CBOW)
Word Representations II — GloVe, word embeddings evaluation and applications
Text Classification — Neural network foundations (feedforward networks for NLP)
N-gram Language Models — Perplexity, smoothing techniques
Part-of-Speech Tagging — HMMs, Viterbi algorithm, CRFs
Syntactic Parsing I — Constituency parsing (CFGs, CKY algorithm)
Syntactic Parsing II — Dependency parsing (transition-based and graph-based)
Recurrent Neural Networks — RNNs, LSTMs, GRUs for sequence modeling
Sequence-to-Sequence Models — Encoder-decoder architectures
Attention Mechanisms and Transformers — Self-attention, multi-head attention
Pre-trained Language Models — BERT, GPT, transfer learning for NLP
Sentiment Analysis and Opinion Mining — Named entity recognition
Question Answering — Coreference resolution, course review

courses.name: Database Systems
courses.description: Almost all large data processing systems rely on a generalized database to store and retrieve data. Course contents include introduction to databases, entity relationship model, physical database design and access strategies, relational data model, SQL data manipulation language, normal forms and logical database design.
courses.keywords: database systems, relational model, SQL, storage, indexing, query processing, transactions, recovery, distributed databases

content.topic: Course Introduction and Relational Model — Database concepts, relational algebra
Modern SQL — Aggregation, joins, nested queries, common table expressions
Database Storage I — Disk-based architecture, file organization, page layout
Database Storage II — Log-structured storage, storage models, data compression
Memory Management — Buffer pool manager, replacement policies (LRU, Clock)
Hash Tables and Indexing I — Static and dynamic hashing, extendible hashing
Indexing II — B+ Trees — Structure, operations (insert, delete, search)
Midterm Exam
Query Processing I — Sorting algorithms, aggregation, join algorithms
Query Processing II — Hash joins, query execution models
Query Optimization — Cost-based optimization, selectivity estimation
Transaction Processing — ACID properties, two-phase locking, deadlock handling
Multi-Version Concurrency Control and Recovery — MVCC, ARIES recovery algorithm
Distributed Databases — Distributed architectures, OLTP vs. OLAP, course wrap-up

courses.name: Artificial Intelligence
courses.description: Artificial intelligence (AI) has become an important field of study with a wide spread of applications. In this module we will investigate questions about AI systems such as: how to represent knowledge, how to effectively generate appropriate sequences of actions and how to search among alternatives to find optimal solutions.
courses.keywords: artificial intelligence, search, CSPs, game playing, MDPs, reinforcement learning, probabilistic reasoning, logic, planning

content.topic: Introduction to AI — History, applications, and intelligent agents
Search Algorithms I — Uninformed search (BFS, DFS, uniform cost search)
Search Algorithms II — Informed search (A*, heuristics, admissibility)
Constraint Satisfaction Problems — CSP formulation, backtracking, arc consistency
Game Playing I — Adversarial search (minimax algorithm)
Game Playing II — Alpha-beta pruning, evaluation functions, Monte Carlo tree search
Markov Decision Processes — MDPs, Bellman equations, value iteration
Reinforcement Learning — Policy iteration, Q-learning, exploration vs. exploitation
Probabilistic Reasoning I — Bayesian networks (structure, conditional independence)
Probabilistic Reasoning II — Inference in Bayesian networks (variable elimination)
Hidden Markov Models — Forward algorithm, Viterbi algorithm
Knowledge Representation and Propositional Logic
First-Order Logic — Syntax, semantics, inference, unification
Planning and Review — STRIPS, forward/backward planning, course summary

courses.name: Cloud Computing
courses.description: Aim of this course are introduce the basics of the emerging cloud computing paradigms and implement basic cloud related applications. Students will familiarize with distributed system models and enabling technologies; virtual machines and virtualization of clusters, networks and data centers.
courses.keywords: cloud computing, virtualization, containers, distributed systems, storage, networking, AWS, Azure, GCP, security

content.topic: Introduction to Cloud Computing — Cloud definition, characteristics (NIST), cloud economics
Cloud Service Models Deep Dive — IaaS, PaaS, SaaS, emerging models (BaaS, FaaS)
Cloud Deployment Models — Public, private, hybrid, multi-cloud strategies

courses.name: User Interface Design
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with a general appreciation of the art of user interface design, particularly graphical user interfaces in computer and software systems with a target of Full Stack Development. It provides extensive case scenarios and examples of bad design.
courses.keywords: HCI, user-centered design, user research, prototyping, visual design, usability, accessibility, mobile UI

content.topic: Introduction to HCI and User-Centered Design Principles
Human Factors — Perception, cognition, and memory in interface design
User Research Methods — Interviews, observation, contextual inquiry
Needfinding, Task Analysis, and User Requirements
Personas, Scenarios, and User Journey Mapping
Conceptual Models and Interaction Design Frameworks
Paper Prototyping and Low-Fidelity Wireframing
Visual Design Principles — Layout, typography, color, hierarchy
Digital Prototyping — Interactive mockups with Figma/Sketch
Usability Evaluation — Heuristic evaluation and cognitive walkthrough
User Testing Methods — Think-aloud protocols and A/B testing
Accessibility and Inclusive Design — WCAG guidelines
Mobile and Responsive Interface Design
Emerging Interfaces — Voice UI, gesture, future of HCI

courses.name: Cryptography
courses.description: This course is on the applications of real world cryptography. It covers fundamental aspects of secure communication and modern implications of privacy by introducing basic and advanced methods of cryptography. Necessary theoretical concepts from number theory, finite fields, elliptic curves are covered.
courses.keywords: cryptography, symmetric, asymmetric, AES, MAC, hash functions, Diffie-Hellman, RSA, digital signatures, PKI, TLS, post-quantum

content.topic: Introduction to Cryptography and Historical Ciphers
Perfect Secrecy — One-time pad, stream ciphers
Block Ciphers and the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES)
Modes of Operation — ECB, CBC, CTR, semantic security
Message Authentication Codes (MAC) and HMAC
Cryptographic Hash Functions — SHA family, Merkle-Damgård construction
Authenticated Encryption and AEAD Modes
Number Theory Foundations for Public-Key Cryptography
Diffie-Hellman Key Exchange and Discrete Logarithm Problem
RSA Encryption and the Factoring Assumption
Digital Signatures — RSA, DSA, ECDSA
Public Key Infrastructure and Certificate Management
Cryptographic Protocols and TLS/SSL
Post-Quantum Cryptography and Zero-Knowledge Proofs

courses.name: Computer Security and Digital Forensics
courses.description: This course introduces students to the fundamentals of computer system security and digital forensics. Emphasis is placed on identifying threats to, and vulnerabilities of, computer systems and how to minimize them. Students will learn how hackers identify victims and how attacks are executed.
courses.keywords: computer security, vulnerabilities, exploits, malware, network security, web security, digital forensics, incident response

content.topic: Introduction to Computer Security — Threat modeling, security principles
Vulnerabilities and Attack Surfaces — Buffer overflows and memory safety
Control-Flow Attacks — Return-oriented programming and defenses
Malware Types — Analysis techniques and defense mechanisms
Network Security Fundamentals and Protocol Vulnerabilities
Intrusion Detection Systems and Network Monitoring
Web Security — SQL injection, XSS, CSRF, secure coding
Authentication, Authorization, and Access Control Models
Introduction to Digital Forensics — Principles and legal framework
Evidence Collection — Preservation and chain of custody
Disk Forensics — File systems, data recovery, analysis tools
Memory Forensics and Live System Analysis
Incident Response — Detection, containment, eradication, recovery
Forensic Reporting — Expert testimony and case studies
